Enthusiast to Data Professional - What changes?
¶

"At the bustling Times Square" - Photo by Saulo Mohana | Unsplash

1. Introduction
¶

I'm sure many of you have read articles about all the buzz words in our community - "Machine Learning", "Data Scientist", "AI" and so on. Some have even branded data science as the "sexiest job of the 21st century"! While these articles go on about the high earnings and the supposed demand for them, very rarely do they go in to what it takes to work with data. They even tend to throw around a lot of terms like "data analyst", "business analyst", "machine learning engineer" without ever explaining what each one specifically deals with, while often using them interchangably.

In this notebook I aim to provide to all the enthusiasts in our community a better understanding of the field, the different jobs that work with data and what do they actually do in their day-to-day work. It also gives students a better insight into what technologies are used and hopefully will empower them with the information to help them break into some of these fields.

I will also keep this notebook rather short, while I do enjoy designing graphs I am strong believer of quality over quantity so I will avoid bombarding you'll with any more information than is necessary, just for the sake of displaying data.

Criteria to be considered as a data professional
¶

In this analysis I will consider data professionals as those who have described their work to include at least one of the following tasks(responses to "Q23. Select any activities that make up an important part of your role at work"):

  • Analyze and understand data to influence product or business decisions
  • Build and/or run the data infrastructure that my business uses for storing, analyzing, and operationalizing data
  • Build prototypes to explore applying machine learning to new areas
  • Build and/or run a machine learning service that operationally improves my product or workflows
  • Experimentation and iteration to improve existing ML models
  • Do research that advances the state of the art of machine learning

There was a small number of people who seemed to be employed but didn't respond to any of the fields in Q23, so I have omitted those entries for our analysis purpose.

I also avoided any age restrictions that would exclude those that just joined into the field from being considered as data professionals because not only would it be subjective to decide how much experience one needs to be considered an expert, but also it's these individuals that are of most interest to enthusiasts as they too would like to understand what set them apart to land that job.

2. Meet the Professionals
¶

This section will cover the different fields that make up our data professionals and how their roles differ from one another. We gain a better understanding of the companies in which they work and what are the salaries like in their line of work.

2.2 The data science life cycle
¶

We will talk about a lot of tools and processes throughout the course of this notebook. This section will go over the basic steps and terminology in the data life cycle and will help enthusiasts understand how each of the discussed tools fit into the actual workflow.

This process is rarely linear and often occurs over multiple iterations. While the order of stages or terminology might be different, a basic overview of the stages in handling and working with data are as follows:

  1. Problem Identification
  2. Business Understanding
  3. Data Acquisition
  4. Data Cleaning
  5. Data Visualisation
  6. Feature Engineering
  7. Model Training
  8. Deployment

1. Problem Identification

Often when starting out, the objective of a data science project might be rather ambiguous or we might lack an understanding of what exactly is the problem and how it affects all the parties involved. We remedy this by asking questions - a lot of them . We try get a better understanding of the domain and the root cause of the problem by speaking to the stakeholders and industry experts. Literature reviews and surveys will also help us decide what data we might want to collect and use.

2. Business Understanding

At this stage we try to define the business objective behind our data science problem. For example, we might be analysing prospective market segments with the business objective of increasing the company's market share and the resulting profits. Identifying such a business objective helps us define our success criteria for the project. We also define the metrics that will help us track our progress towards our objective:

  • KPI(Key Performance Indicator): Measure your performance against key business objectives. Businesses use this to measure their performance against objectives and the overall health of their business.

  • SLA(Service Level Agreement): These describe the level of service that will be provided to the client. It defines the metrics by which the performance will measured and also the penalties incurred if these standards aren't met.

    Poorly designed metrics will affect how the product is priced, customer experience and the overall company reputation, so its important to get this right.

3. Data Acquisition

In most data science industry projects, you will be using data that already exists and is being collected. Occasionally, youll be leading efforts to collect new data, but that can be a lot of engineering work and it can take a while to bear fruit. This is an iterative process often using an ETL/ELT pipeline consisting of the main stages:

  • Extract: Extraction refers to pulling the source data from the original database or data source. With ETL, the data goes into a temporary staging area. With ELT, it goes immediately into a data lake storage system.
  • Transform: Transformation refers to the process of changing the structure of the information, so it integrates with the target data system and the rest of the data in that system.
  • Load: Loading refers to the process of depositing the information into a data storage system.

4. Data Cleaning

Just because the data is loaded into storage doesn't mean that its ready to be used in your analysis. Collected data may be full of issues like corrupted data, incorrectly formatted or invalid entries, duplicate data, etc. Remedying this is a time consuming process, because each field having missing or incorrect data begs another question as to why something went wrong that caused this to happen and also how do we fix this incorrect data. Such a task takes a great deal of manual effort and expertise to perform which soaks up a large chunk of data professionals' time.

5. Data Visualisation

We now explore the data, looking for patterns and insights that might be worth investigating through the use of graphs and charts. Data visualisation is important not only in data exploration, but also when understanding our tracked metrics and communicating our results to answer our clients' most important questions.

6. Feature Engineering

We utilise domain knowledge to craft features that will improve the performance of our machine learning model. This often involves applying data transforms like log transformation, binning, category encoding, etc. In this step we may also attempt to mitigate any bias in the data, remove outliers, etc.

7. Model Training

We start out by developing a baseline model that we will use as a reference against which we will test later models. This is an iterative process as one experiments with different algorithms, network architectures as well as the choice for loss metrics and hyperparameters used.

8. Model Deployment Now we need to deploy our model so that it may be used by either the business or the client. Before you deploy a model, there are a couple of criteria that your machine learning model needs to achieve before its ready for deployment:

  • Portability: this refers to the ability of your software to be transferred from one machine or system to another. A portable model is one with a relatively low response time and one that can be rewritten with minimal effort.
  • Scalability: this refers to how large your model can scale. A scalable model is one that doesnt need to be redesigned to maintain its performance.

If you wish to read further on these topics I'd recommend the following articles:

  • The Data Science Process: What a data scientist actually does day-to-day
  • The Generic Data Science Life-Cycle

2.3 Workflow of Data Professionals
¶

While we do gain a basic idea of the roles our data professionals perform our survey question, I would still like to shed some light on the actual workflow of a data professional and how the previous activities factor into their daily work. For this we turn to Anaconda's State of Data Science Report 2020 where they asked data scientists to assign a percentage of time spent to each stage of their data work. This helps us understand how much time is spent in each area of the workflow from start to end(top to bottom, in the diagram).

Source: Anaconda State of DS Report 2020 - Thinking about your current job, how much of your time is spent in each of the following tasks?

js_t1 = '''
         require.config({
            paths: {
                d3: "https://d3js.org/d3.v4.min"
             }
             });
        require(["d3"], function(d3) {
        
         // set the dimensions and margins of the graph
        var margin_stages = {top: 15, right: 30, bottom: 30, left:0},
            width_stages = 460 - margin_stages.left - margin_stages.right,
            height_stages = 400 - margin_stages.top - margin_stages.bottom;
        
        // append the svg object to the body of the page
        var svg = d3.select("#stages_viz")
          .append("svg")
            .attr("width", width_stages + margin_stages.left + margin_stages.right)
            .attr("height", height_stages + margin_stages.top + margin_stages.bottom)
          .append("g")
            .attr("transform",
                  "translate(" + margin_stages.left + "," + margin_stages.top + ")");
        
        // Create a map for titles
        var title_data_stages = {
            "dl" : "Data loading",
            "dc" : "Data cleansing",
            "dv" : "Data visualisation",
            "ms" : "Model selection",
            "mt" : "Model training and scoring",
            "dm" : "Deploying models"
        }
        
        // Create a map for desc
        var desc_data_stages = {
            "dl" : "Retrieve and combine data from different sources.",
            "dc" : "Remove or fix incorrect, duplicate or missing data.",
            "dv" : "Graphical representation of data, to spot patterns.",
            "ms" : "The task of selecting the best candidate model.",
            "mt" : "Applying algorithms to the data and scoring them.",
            "dm" : "Deployment of models into production."
        }

        // Parse the Data
        d3.csv("stages.csv", function(data) {
        
          var subgroups = data.columns.slice(1)
        
          var groups = d3.map(data, function(d){return(d.group)}).keys()
        
          // Add X axis, and hide it
          var x = d3.scaleBand()
              .domain(groups)
              .range([0, width_stages])
              .padding([0.2])
          svg.append("g")
            .style("display","none")
            .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height_stages + ")")
            .call(d3.axisBottom(x).tickSizeOuter(0));
        
          // Add Y axis, and hide it
          var y = d3.scaleLinear()
            .domain([0, 105])
            .range([ height_stages, 0 ])
          svg.append("g")
            .style("display","none")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y));
        
          var color = d3.scaleLinear()
            .domain([0,2,5])
            .range(['#202022','#3f4d63','#c6ccd8'])
        
          var stackedData = d3.stack()
            .keys(subgroups)
            (data)
        
          // Show the bars
        var chart =  svg.append("g")
            .selectAll("g")
            .data(stackedData)
            .enter().append("g")
              .attr("fill", function(d) { return color(d.index); })
              .selectAll("rect")
              .data(function(d) { return d; })
              .enter().append("rect")
                .attr("x", function(d) { return x(d.data.group); })
                .attr("y", function(d) { return y(d[1]); })
                .attr("height", function(d) { return y(d[0]) - y(d[1]); })
                .attr("width",100)
        
        // Creates the text elements for percentage on the stacked bar chart
        svg
            .selectAll("text.perc")
            .data(stackedData)
                .enter()
                .append("text")
                .attr("class","perc")
                .attr("text-anchor","middle")
                .text((d)=> d[0].data[d.key]+"%")
                .attr("x", function(d) { return x(d[0].data.group) + 52 })
                .attr("y", function(d) { return y((d[0][1] + d[0][0])/2) + 5})
                .style("fill", "white")
        
        // Creates the text elements for titles on the right
        svg
            .selectAll("text.title")
            .data(stackedData)
                .enter()
                .append("text")
                .attr("class","title")
                .attr("text-anchor","start")
                .text((d) => title_data_stages[d.key])
                .attr("x", function(d) {return x(d[0].data.group) + 109 })
                .attr("y", function(d) { return y(d[0][1]) + 16 })
                .style("fill", "black")
                .style("font-weight",600)
                .style("font-family","Tahoma")
                .style("font-size","12px")
        
        // Creates the text elements for descriptions on the right
        svg.selectAll("text.desc")
            .data(stackedData)
                .enter()
                .append("text")
                .attr("class","desc")
                .attr("text-anchor","start")
                .text((d) => desc_data_stages[d.key])
                .attr("x", function(d) { return (x(d[0].data.group) + 110)})
                .attr("y", function(d)  { return ( y(d[0][1]) + 30)})
                .style("color", "#4d4d4d")
                .style("line-height", 1)
                .style("font-family", "Tahoma")
                .style("font-size", "11px")
        })
});
'''

What percentage of time is spent in these activities?

A surprising observation is that a significant amount of time goes into loading and cleaning data(45% of total time). This is a real eye opener because a lot of students will neglect this integral part of data handling and instead focus solely on the more trending machine learning side of things which only comprises 23% of the work.

Perhaps automated tools might also help to reduce the massive chunk of data professionals' time that is sunk into the manual task of loading and cleaning the data, allowing them to focus on the more challenging data science work.

2.4 Data roles in different fields
¶

One thing I always wondered with all these different roles, what exactly do they work on, on a day-to-day basis - It can't all be the same regardless of the job title right?

Another question that has always bothered me(and I'm sure many of you too) - "What's the difference between the roles data scientist, data engineer, data analyst and business analyst?" Lets see if we can answer this in the following graph of data roles.

Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q23. Select any activities that make up an important part of your role at work.
In [7]:
# Create a dataframe that will store value_counts for each field's roles
field_df = pd.DataFrame()
avg_roles = dict()

field_data = df[df[q23_all[0:7]].isnull().sum(axis=1)!=len(q23_all[0:7])]
df_q23 = df[df[q23].isnull().sum(axis=1) != len(q23)]

for field in fields:
    temp_df = field_data[field_data["Q5"]==field]
    field_df[field] = temp_df[q23_all[:7]].count()/temp_df[q23_all[:7]].shape[0]
    avg_roles[field]= (temp_df[q23_all[:7]].count(axis=1).mean())
    
field_df.drop("Other", axis=1, inplace=True)

# shortened version of labels
labels = [
    'Analyze data for business decisions',
    'Build the data infrastructure',
    'Build ML prototypes in new areas',
    'Build ML services for products/workflows',
    'Improving existing ML models',
    'Research to advance ML',
    'None']

traces = dict()

    # Since we want to show even "None" we use df_q23 instead of dataprofs

    )

    colors_list[max_indexes[0]] = primary_blue
    colors_list[max_indexes[1]] = primary_blue2

    orientation = "h",

    )
    traces[field] = trace

fig = subplots.make_subplots(
    rows=5,

fig.append_trace(traces["Statistician"],3,1);              fig.append_trace(traces["Research Scientist"],3,2);
fig.append_trace(traces["Machine Learning Engineer"],4,1); fig.append_trace(traces["Product/Project Manager"],4,2);
fig.append_trace(traces["DBA/Database Engineer"],5,1);     fig.append_trace(traces["Software Engineer"],5,2);

small_title_format = "<span style='font-size:14px; font-family:Helvetica'>  The length of the bars denotes the <b>percentage of professionals in the field that perform the specified activity</b>.</span>"

As for the answer to our previous question:

  • For all the four titles(first 4 bar charts), the main focus remains analysing data for business decisions.
  • Data analysts and Business Analysts seem to be almost identical with respect to the role distribution and average number of roles per individual.
  • Data engineers seem to be similar to the others, except for their significant focus on building infrastructure for the data management and analysis.
  • Finally data scientists also have a higher focus on building ML prototypes in a new areas as well as have a relatively higher number of roles on average. Both these traits make it very similar to Machine Learning Engineers(except for the focus on impacting business decisions).

Another interesting detail is machine learning engineers, true to their name, show higher numbers across the board for all the ML related roles. Even their work in research on state of the art ML methods, is only second to research scientists themselves.

Some interesting points to note:

  • 70% of students in the age group 18-21 are pursuing a Bachelor's degree.
  • In the 22-24 age group, the focus shifts towards Masters, having a marked jump from 11% to 45% in this age group. Meanwhile the percentage of Bachelors degree holders drops to below 40% for the first time.
  • In later age, groups the proportion Masters still remains around the 40-60% mark, with Doctoral degrees as a close second, while the numbers for bachelors slowly decreases.
  • On the data professional side of things, we see that most fields have a majority of their respondents in the 25-29 age group.
  • The sole exception to this is Project Managers, which peaks at 35-39. Most likely because these are positions you would only enter after a fair deal of experience. This also helps explain their relatively higher pays that we noted in the previous section.

The general trend seems to be that more than half of the individuals in each field seem to have either a Master's or Bachelor's degree in almost all fields. A notable exception being Research Scientists where more than half the respondents have doctoral degrees and when you include Masters and Professional degree holders this number comprises of 93% of the total professionals in their field.

Some additional points of interest:

  • In most fields Masters degree seems to be the way to go with 30-55% of respondents having one.
  • A bachelors degree seems to be a close second with numbers around the 20-30% mark.
  • Professional degrees seem to be a less common choice with around 4-5% having one. Hovewer they do help to get jobs because professional degree holders have the second lowest fraction of unemployed individuals, after Doctoral degree holders.

2.7.1 Handling Regional bias in pays
¶

Salaries aren't really comparable by simply converting to USD and then drawing conclusions from this data. A major factor in this is the cost of living in different countries - Companies situated in places where costs of living are higher pay their employees more to compensate for this. A simple example would be how 100$ would have different purchasing power in different places.

I'll handle this disparity by dividing each respondents salary by their country's cost of living index and then converting this value to an equivalent amount in USD. A simple demonstration of how this affects reported salaries is shown below

Source: Countries Dataset 2020 - Numbeo: Cost of living index
In [10]:
# Map to convert bins to mid point amount.
earnings_map ={
 '$0-999': 500,
 '100,000-124,999': 112500,
 '10,000-14,999': 12500,
 '1,000-1,999': 1500,
 '40,000-49,999': 45000,
 '30,000-39,999': 35000,
 '50,000-59,999': 55000,
 '5,000-7,499': 6250,
 '15,000-19,999': 17500,
 '70,000-79,999': 75000,
 '60,000-69,999': 65000,
 '20,000-24,999': 22500,
 '150,000-199,999': 175000,
 '7,500-9,999': 8650,
 '125,000-149,999': 137500,
 '2,000-2,999': 2500,
 '25,000-29,999': 27500,
 '90,000-99,999': 95000,
 '80,000-89,999': 85000,
 '4,000-4,999': 4500,
 '3,000-3,999': 3500,
 '200,000-249,999': 225000,
 '300,000-500,000': 400000,
 '250,000-299,999': 275000,
 '> $500,000': 600000
}

# Loading cost of living index data
col_path = "./Cost of living index by country 2020.csv"
col = pd.read_csv(col_path)

col_index = col[["Country","Cost of Living Index"]] 

# We'll need this later to convert everything back to its USD equivalent
USA_coli = col_index[col_index["Country"]== "United States"]["Cost of Living Index"].values[0]

# Replacing the names which don't match across the two datasets
dataprofs_with_salary = dataprofs.replace("United States of America","United States")
dataprofs_with_salary = dataprofs_with_salary.replace("Viet Nam","Vietnam")
dataprofs_with_salary = dataprofs_with_salary.replace("Republic of Korea","South Korea")
dataprofs_with_salary = dataprofs_with_salary.replace("United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland","United Kingdom")
dataprofs_with_salary = dataprofs_with_salary.replace("Iran, Islamic Republic of...","Iran")

# Merge on countries and drop all professionals that haven't reported any salary
dataprofs_with_salary = pd.merge(dataprofs_with_salary,col_index, left_on="Q3", right_on="Country")
dataprofs_with_salary = dataprofs_with_salary.dropna(axis=0, subset=["Q24"])

# amount - bins converted to a dollar amount, norm - amount / cost of living index, norm_US equivalent amount in USD
dataprofs_with_salary["Q24_amount"] = [earnings_map[row] for row in dataprofs_with_salary["Q24"].values]
dataprofs_with_salary["Q24_norm"] = dataprofs_with_salary["Q24_amount"]/dataprofs_with_salary["Cost of Living Index"]
dataprofs_with_salary["Q24_norm_US"] = dataprofs_with_salary["Q24_norm"] * USA_coli

# Creating dfs for the example
salary_eg_india = dataprofs_with_salary[dataprofs_with_salary["Q3"]=="India"]
salary_eg_us = dataprofs_with_salary[dataprofs_with_salary["Q3"]=="United States"]

field_avg_pays_ind = pd.DataFrame()

for field in fields:
    field_avg_pays_ind[field] = [dataprofs_with_salary[(dataprofs_with_salary["Q3"]=="India") & (dataprofs_with_salary["Q5"]==field)]["Q24_amount"].mean(),
                                 dataprofs_with_salary[(dataprofs_with_salary["Q3"]=="India") & (dataprofs_with_salary["Q5"]==field)]["Q24_norm_US"].mean()
                            ]

field_avg_pays_ind.index = ["original","normalised"]
field_avg_pays_ind = field_avg_pays_ind.T

field_avg_pays_us = pd.DataFrame()

for field in fields:
    field_avg_pays_us[field] = [dataprofs_with_salary[(dataprofs_with_salary["Q3"]=="United States") & (dataprofs_with_salary["Q5"]==field)]["Q24_amount"].mean(),
                                 dataprofs_with_salary[(dataprofs_with_salary["Q3"]=="United States") & (dataprofs_with_salary["Q5"]==field)]["Q24_norm_US"].mean()
                            ]

field_avg_pays_us.index = ["original","normalised"]
field_avg_pays_us = field_avg_pays_us.T

# Binning amounts
bins = [0,2500,10000,25000,50000,100000,250000,500000, 1000000]

salary_eg_india["amount_bins"] = pd.cut(salary_eg_india["Q24_amount"], bins)
salary_eg_india["norm_US_bins"] = pd.cut(salary_eg_india["Q24_norm_US"], bins)
salary_eg_us["amount_bins"] = pd.cut(salary_eg_us["Q24_amount"], bins)

order = [str(interval.left)+"-<br>"+str(interval.right) for interval in np.sort(salary_eg_india["amount_bins"].unique())]

# Creating graph
trace1 = go.Bar(
    y = salary_eg_india["amount_bins"].value_counts(),
    x = [str(interval.left)+"-<br>"+str(interval.right) for interval in salary_eg_india["amount_bins"].value_counts().index],
    name = "India - before",
    marker = dict(color = primary_grey),
)

trace2 = go.Bar(
    y = salary_eg_india["norm_US_bins"].value_counts(),
    x = [str(interval.left)+"-<br>"+str(interval.right) for interval in salary_eg_india["norm_US_bins"].value_counts().index],
    name = "India - after",
    marker = dict(color = primary_blue2),
)

trace3 = go.Bar(
    y = salary_eg_us["amount_bins"].value_counts(),
    x = [str(interval.left)+"-<br>"+str(interval.right) for interval in salary_eg_us["amount_bins"].value_counts().index],
    name = "USA",
    marker = dict(color = primary_blue),
)

layout = dict(
#     title = 
    margin = dict(l=0),
    xaxis= dict(
            categoryorder = 'array',
            categoryarray = order,
    ),
    yaxis= dict(
            domain=[0.55,1],
            showgrid = False,
            zeroline = True,
            zerolinewidth = 1,
            zerolinecolor = "#4d4d4d"
    ),
    xaxis2={'categoryorder':'array',
           'categoryarray': order},
    yaxis2= dict(
            domain=[0,0.45],
            showgrid = False,
            zeroline = True,
            zerolinewidth = 1,
            zerolinecolor = "#4d4d4d"
    ),
    barmode = "group",
    legend=dict(yanchor='top',xanchor='center',y=0.99,x=0.587,font=dict(family="Tahoma",size= 12),traceorder='normal'),
    plot_bgcolor = "#fff",
    width = 800,
    height=700,
)

title_format = "<span style='font-size:20px; font-family:Times New Roman'>%s</span>"

fig = subplots.make_subplots(rows=2, cols=1, subplot_titles=[title_format % "Before considering cost of living ($)" + " "*70,title_format % "After considering cost of living ($)" + " "*70])
fig.append_trace(trace1,1,1)
fig.append_trace(trace3,1,1)
fig.append_trace(trace2,2,1)
fig.append_trace(trace3,2,1)

fig.add_vrect(x0=3.5, x1=7.6,
              xref = "paper",
              yref = "y2",
              fillcolor= "#e9cf87",
              layer="below", 
              opacity=0.25, 
              line_width=0
)

# Annotations section

main_annot_format = "<span style='font-size:11px; font-family:Tahoma;'><b> %s </b><br> %s</span>"

fig.add_annotation(dict(
        x=0.865,
        y=0.75,
        xref = "paper",
        yref = "paper",
        text= main_annot_format % ("50,000 USD and upwards",
                                   """Before taking  into  account  the cost<br>of living only  <b>10%</b>  of Indians make<br>more   than   50,000$,   much  lower<br>than the 59% shown by respondents<br>working in USA."""),
        ax=0, ay=0
))

fig.add_annotation(dict(
        x=0.865,
        y=0.22,
        xref = "paper",
        yref = "paper",
        text= main_annot_format % ("50,000 USD and upwards - <br>after normalising",
                                   """The adjusted  salaries  in  India  bring <br>our  observations  more  in  line  with<br>those seen in the US, with <b>30%</b> now<br>making more than 50,000$."""),
        ax=0, ay=0
))

fig.add_annotation(dict(
        x=0.180,
        y=0.24,
        xref = "paper",
        yref = "paper",
        text= main_annot_format % ("Shift to higher pay ranges",
                                   """There is  a  noticeable reduction<br>in the number of Indians in the<br>lower pay  ranges as compared<br>to the above graph."""),
        ax=0, ay=0
))

fig['layout'].update(layout)

# Prevent USA from showing up twice in legend
fig["data"][3]["showlegend"] = False
iplot(fig)

We see how a country like India, where the cost of living is much lower than that of the US, has the majority of its individuals towards the lower end of the graph. However on normalising with the cost of living data, we see how a much larger portion of Indians enter the higher pay brackets. In fact the salaries in India are almost tripled to get their corrected values.

While this won't be a 100% accurate it gives us a much better basis on which we may compare salaries. And in this case we would probably be safe to assume that in general, companies in the US just do pay their data experts more.

2.7.2 Company size and Earnings
¶

Maybe there might be a difference in these closely related fields based on where the sizes of the organisations. Perhaps certain roles might be more common than in certain organisation structures? Perhaps there is a marked pay difference between them?

Let's see if we can answer these questions with the following illustration. Note that we will use the normalised US equivalents of each respondents pay here.

Sources: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey -
  • Q20. What is the size of the company where you are employed?
  • Q5. Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired)
  • Q24. What is your current yearly compensation (approximate USD)?
In [11]:
companysize_labels_original = ['0-49 employees', '50-249 employees', '250-999 employees', '1000-9,999 employees', '10,000 or more employees']

# dfs for count and salary data.
company_count_data = dataprofs_with_salary.groupby(["Q5"])["Q20"].value_counts()
company_sal_data = np.round(dataprofs_with_salary.groupby(["Q5","Q20"])["Q24_norm_US"].mean())

count_sal_data_list = [] 
for field in fields:
    for cosize in companysize_labels_original:
        count_sal_data_list.append([
            cosize.split(" emp")[0],
            field,
            company_count_data[field][cosize],
            np.int32(company_sal_data[field][cosize]),
            company_count_data[field][cosize] * np.round(company_sal_data[field][cosize])
        ])

count_sal_data_df = pd.DataFrame(count_sal_data_list, columns = ["size","field","count","sal","prop"])

# Shortening some of the labels in the CSV 
count_sal_data_df = count_sal_data_df.replace("Machine Learning Engineer","ML Engineer")
count_sal_data_df = count_sal_data_df.replace("Product/Project Manager","Project Manager")

# Write out for use in D3
count_sal_data_df.to_csv("count_sal_data.csv", index=False)

js_t1 = '''
         require.config({
            paths: {
                d3: "https://d3js.org/d3.v4.min"
             }
             });
        require(["d3"], function(d3) {
        
        // Map for title data
         var titleData = {
            "count" : "Counts of Professionals across company sizes",
            "salary": "Compensation of Professionals across company sizes",
            "money" : "Spending on Data Professionals"
        }
        
        // Map for description data
        var descData = {
            "count" : "Data scientists form the bulk of our respondents. Working in more tight-knit companies with less than 50 employees is also common among data professionals.",
            "salary": "In general larger companies tend to pay their data professionals more, with minor exceptions. In professions like Project Manager and DBA experience is greatly valued, resulting in higher pays (all amounts in USD).",
            "money" : "A product of the previous two graphs, this graph gives us a sense of all the money these companies spend on data professionals, where is it concentrated? Well, of the 513B USD spent on data-related work, almost a third of it (137B USD) goes towards Data Scientists."
        }

        // set the dimensions and margins of the graph
        var margin_count_sal = { top: 20, right: 0, bottom: 30, left: 95 },
            width_count_sal = 610 - margin_count_sal.left - margin_count_sal.right,
            height_count_sal = 500 - margin_count_sal.top - margin_count_sal.bottom;

        // append the svg object to the body of the page
        var svg = d3.select("#dataviz_count_sal")
            .append("svg")
            .attr("width", width_count_sal + margin_count_sal.left + margin_count_sal.right)
            .attr("height", height_count_sal + margin_count_sal.top + margin_count_sal.bottom)
            .append("g")
            .attr("transform",
                "translate(" + margin_count_sal.left + "," + margin_count_sal.top + ")");

        // Labels of row and columns
        var xlabels = ['0-49 employees', '50-249 employees', '250-999 employees', '1000-9,999 employees', '10,000 or more employees']
        var ylabels = ['Data Engineer', 'Data Scientist', 'Research Scientist', 'Statistician', 'Project Manager', 'Data Analyst', 'Software Engineer', 'ML Engineer', 'Other', 'Business Analyst', 'DBA/Database Engineer']

        // Build X scales and axis:
        var x = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([0, width_count_sal])
            .domain(xlabels)
            .padding(0.01);

        svg.append("g")
            .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height_count_sal + ")")
            .call(d3.axisBottom(x))
            .style("font-size","8px")
                

        // Build X scales and axis:
        var y = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([height_count_sal, 0])
            .domain(ylabels)
            .padding(0.03);

        svg.append("g")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y))

        // Build color scale
        var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
            .range(["#f5f5f5", "#29658c"])
            .domain([1, 216])

        showData();
        let buttons = d3.selectAll(".dv_count_sal button")

        buttons
            .on("click", function(){
                showData(this.value)
            })

        function showData(mode="count"){
                    d3.csv("count_sal_data.csv", function (data) {
                    
                    function getValue(d){
                        if(mode == "count") return +d.count
                        else if(mode == "salary") return +d.sal
                        else return +d.prop
                    }

                    d3.select(".count_sal_title")
                        .text(titleData[mode])
                        .style("position","relative")
                        .style("left","30px")
                        .style("font-family","Times New Roman")
                        .style("font-size", "26px")

                    d3.select(".count_sal_desc")
                        .text(descData[mode])
                        .style("width","560px")
                        .style("position","relative")
                        .style("left","30px")
                        .style("font-family","Tahoma")
                        .style("font-size", "14px")
                        .style("color","#4d4d4d")
                        .style("line-height","normal")
                    
                    var maxColor = d3.max(data, (d)=>{return getValue(d)})
                    var minColor = d3.min(data, (d)=>{return getValue(d)})
                    var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
                    .range(["#f5f5f5", "#29658c"])
                    .domain([minColor, maxColor])
                    
                    // Draw rectangles for cells
                    var u = svg.selectAll("rect")
                    .data(data)
                    
                    u
                    .enter()
                    .append("rect")
                    .merge(u)
                    .transition()
                    .duration(1000)
                    .attr("x", function (d) { return x(d.size + " employees")})
                    .attr("y", function (d) { return y(d.field) })
                    .attr("width", x.bandwidth())
                    .attr("height", y.bandwidth())
                    .style("fill", function (d) { if(d.count !=="nan"){return myColor(getValue(d));} return myColor(0);  })
                    
                    // Text labels for the cells
                    var v = svg.selectAll("svg > g > text")
                    .data(data)

                    v
                    .enter()
                    .append("text")
                    .merge(v)
                    .transition()
                    .duration(1000)
                    .text( function (d) { if(getValue(d) !=="nan" && getValue(d) != 0){ return getValue(d).toString().replace(/\B(?=(\d{3})+(?!\d))/g, ",")} return " "; })
                    .attr("x", function (d) { return x(d.size + " employees")})
                    .attr("y", function (d) { return y(d.field) })
                    .attr("text-anchor","middle")
                    .attr("transform","translate(55,26)")
                    .style("font-family","Didot")
                    .style("font-size","16px")
                    .style("fill", function (d){if(getValue(d) > maxColor/2) { return "#f5f5f5"}; return "black";})
        })
    }

});
'''

NOTE: With earnings data split into bins in the dataset, I have considered the individual's earnings to be the midpoint of each bin for the purpose of averaging. Since this makes the data inaccurate, it is only meant to give a basic idea of how the pays differ across different fields and company sizes.

While there is a lot to look at in the graph, some common themes seem to be:

  • The general distribution of experts across company sizes seems to remain roughly the same for all fields.
  • A majority of them work in companies with 0-50 employees, although their pay remains on the lower end of the scale.
  • Larger companies tend to pay more in general.
  • Companies seem to be investing massive amounts in their data scientist as compared to the other fields(as shown in the "Overall compensation" tab).

2.8 Machine Learning practices
¶

So.. you want to work in machine learning? Well, lets give you a better idea of the type of ML-related work you might encounter in certain fields.

Sources: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q22. Does your current employer incorporate machine learning methods into their business?

# Notes: ~ 4.5-5hrs on this one
# Had to find a workaround for requiring both stacked and overlay barmodes in the same graph
# Blank annotation texts for the arrows also worked out well

In case you are unclear on what exactly "production" means I'll give you a little background here - Traditionally, when a data scientist would create an ML model they would often do so in a sandbox or development environment. This is great for experimenting and reiterating quickly, however in order for the consumers to use it, the model must be deployed so that it scales well with increased usage volumes and is always available for use by others. This deployment however, requires a skill-set different than what most data scientists possess and often this burden falls on the Software Engineers.

In order for a ML product to be put into production both teams must work closely and this cooperation is what a lot of companies dealing in ML products strive for. This back-and-forth forms the basis by which they manage to build and maintain well established ML models. (You can read more about this here.)

Now back to the graph - an interesting observation is how Machine Learning Engineers ranked second here in terms of well-established ML production practices, this is the exact situation where ML Engineers shine - they are a mix of both Software Engineers and Data Scientists whose main role is to take machine learning models and make them scalable in production.

The left-most bar also shows us what proportion of the companies don't utilise ML methods in their daily activities.

3. What should I focus on?
¶

Now that we have a good idea of the different fields that work with data, lets take a deeper dive to understand what tools are commonly used and about trends in the industry. We will use the data professionals' responses to find out where we should focus our learning efforts.

3.1 The Skills Gap
¶

A lot of enterprises express that their recruits fresh out of their degree courses often lack certain fundamentals to seamlessly fit into the workplace. This may be attributed to their universities not prioritising certain key skills or perhaps due to the lack of initiative taken by the students in learning by themselves. In Anaconda's State of Data Science Report 2020, respondents working in industry backgrounds were asked what were some of the essential skills that their newer recruits lacked. On the other side of things, students were even asked what they chose to study in preparation for their work.

Source: Anaconda's State of DS Report 2020 - The Skills Gap
In [13]:

While these numbers are specifically for the field of data science, it does still give us an idea of where there is a disconnect between what the students learn and what is actually expected of them in the workplace. Some of the areas where students seem to be lacking are:

  • Big data management: When people talk about big data, one of the first things that come to a lot of peoples' mind is deep learning and how it leverages massive volumes of data to generate powerful models. Rarely does one think of big data management which actually encompasses the entire range of policies, procedures and technologies that are utilised in the organization and administration of large repositories of data. Often students will glaze over this part of data management because its one of the more mundane parts of the job.
  • Deep Learning and Machine Learning: Based on the specifics of the role, companies also place a lot of importance on the recruit having a good foundation in the working of machine learning and deep learning algorithms as well as a hands-on experience of when to apply these to specfic problems.
  • Advanced Mathematics: While admittedly there are slight variations on the exact content of "advanced mathematics", it is a safe bet that if one wants to work with data they should be well-versed with the basics of algebra, statistics, calculus and trigonometry, and must be comfortable to delve deeper into these topics should their work require it

3.2 Development environments: IDEs and Hosted notebooks
¶

Let us see if there are any note-worthy trends in terms of what tools data professionals use during their development work.

small_title_format = "<span style='font-size:14px; font-family:Helvetica'>        <b>Colab</b> followed by <b>Kaggle notebooks</b> seem to be the main choice for our professionals. Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q10. Which of the following hosted notebook products do you use on a regular basis?

Hosted notebooks provide us access to a hassle free environment in which we may collaborate and share our results with others. For example, even though I dont have R installed on my system, Kaggle will happily let me open up an R notebook and start coding immediately without any setup on my side.

Among those that do use hosted notebooks Colab and Kaggle notebooks are the top two choices. With 28% of individuals responding that they dont any hosted notebooks, we understand that not all roles require their use.

3.3 How much coding experience do I need?
¶

Another interesting question to ask is how much coding experience do I need to start out in these fields? Now, I could just plot the fields vs the average coding experience of its professionals, but this doesn't account for the experience they gained during the course of their career. So it might be more fitting to plot a heatmap of their coding experience against their age, so we know how experienced individuals are at particular age groups in the field.

Also I'm sure many of you have specfic fields that you may be interested in, so feel free to use the buttons to view how the numbers differ across fields.

Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q6. For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?
In [16]:
# NOTE: This cell at times, needs to be run multiple times before the output shows 
# EDIT: works fine now that I removed the script tag that included the d3.js dependency

# Creating the df for d3
experience_labels = ['I have never written code', '< 1 years', '1-2 years', '3-5 years','5-10 years', '10-20 years', '20+ years']

expdata_list = []
max = 0

experience_age_heatmap = pd.DataFrame()

for agegroup in student_ages.keys():
    experience_age_heatmap[agegroup] = dataprofs[dataprofs["Q1"]==agegroup]["Q6"].value_counts().reindex(experience_labels)

expdata = experience_age_heatmap.values

for row in range(expdata.shape[0]):
    for col in range(expdata.shape[1]):
        expdata_list.append([experience_labels[row],student_ages.keys()[col],expdata[row][col],"all"])
        
for field in fields:
    for agegroup in student_ages.keys():
        experience_age_heatmap[agegroup] = dataprofs[(dataprofs["Q1"]==agegroup) & (dataprofs["Q5"]==field)]["Q6"].value_counts().reindex(experience_labels)

    expdata = experience_age_heatmap.values

    for row in range(expdata.shape[0]):
        for col in range(expdata.shape[1]):
            expdata_list.append([experience_labels[row],student_ages.keys()[col],expdata[row][col],field])
            
expdata_df = pd.DataFrame(expdata_list,columns=['group', 'variable', 'value', 'field'])
expdata_df["group"] = ["'"+data+"'" for data in expdata_df["group"]]
expdata_df["variable"] = ["'"+data+"'" for data in expdata_df["variable"]]
expdata_df["field"] = ["'"+data+"'" for data in expdata_df["field"]]

expdata_df.to_csv("experience_heatmap.csv", index=False)

         require.config({
            paths: {
                d3: "https://d3js.org/d3.v4.min"
             }
             });
        require(["d3"], function(d3) {
        var data;
        // set the dimensions and margins of the graph
        var margin = { top: 5, right: 65, bottom: 60, left: 70 },
            width = 750 - margin.left - margin.right,
            height = 600 - margin.top - margin.bottom;

        // append the svg object to the body of the page
        var svg = d3.select("#my_dataviz")
            .append("svg")
            .attr("width", width + margin.left + margin.right)
            .attr("height", height + margin.top + margin.bottom)
            .append("g")
            .attr("transform",
                "translate(" + margin.left + "," + margin.top + ")");

        // Labels of row and columns
        var myGroups = ["'18-21'", "'22-24'", "'25-29'", "'30-34'", "'35-39'", "'40-44'", "'45-49'", "'50-54'", "'55-59'", "'60-69'", "'70+'"];
        var myVars = ["'I have never written code'", "'< 1 years'", "'1-2 years'", "'3-5 years'", "'< 1 years'","'5-10 years'", "'10-20 years'", "'20+ years'"];

        // Build X scales and axis:
        var x = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([0, width])
            .domain(myGroups)
            .padding(0.03);

        svg.append("g")
            .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height + ")")
            .call(d3.axisBottom(x))

        // Build X scales and axis:
        var y = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([height, 0])
            .domain(myVars)
            .padding(0.03);

        svg.append("g")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y));

        // Build color scale
        var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
            .range(["#f5f5f5", "#496595"])
            .domain([1, 216])

        showData()
        
        document.getElementById("ds").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("da").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("de").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("ba").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("ml").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData('Machine Learning Engineer')});
        document.getElementById("rs").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("st").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("ot").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("db").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("se").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData(evt.target.innerHTML)});
        document.getElementById("pm").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData('Product/Project Manager')});
        document.getElementById("all").addEventListener("click", function(evt) {showData("all")});
        
        function changeContent(evt){ showData(evt.target.innerHTML)}
        
        function change(field){
            this.field = field
            showData(field);
        }

        function showData(field="all"){
                    d3.csv("experience_heatmap.csv", function (data) {
               
                    data = data.filter(function(d){
                        return d.field == "'"+field+"'";
                    })
                    
                    var maxColor = d3.max(data, (d)=>{return parseInt(d.value)})
                    var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
                    .range(["#f5f5f5", "#29658c"])
                    .domain([1, maxColor])

                    var u = svg.selectAll("rect")
                    .data(data)

                    u
                    .enter()
                    .append("rect")
                    .merge(u)
                    .transition()
                    .duration(1000)
                    .attr("x", function (d) {return x(d.variable) })
                    .attr("y", function (d) {return y(d.group) })
                    .attr("width", x.bandwidth())
                    .attr("height", y.bandwidth())
                    .style("fill", function (d) { if(d.value !=="nan"){return myColor(d.value);} return myColor(0);  })
                    
                    var v = svg.selectAll("svg > g > text")
                    .data(data)

                    v
                    .enter()
                    .append("text")
                    .merge(v)
                    .transition()
                    .duration(1000)
                    .text( function (d) { if(d.value !=="nan"){ return d.value.split(".")[0];} return 0;  })
                    .attr("x", function (d) { return x(d.variable) })
                    .attr("y", function (d) { return y(d.group) })
                    .attr("transform","translate(10,50)")
                    .style("font-family","Didot")
                    .style("font-size","24px")
                    .style("fill", function (d){if(d.value > maxColor/2) { return "#f5f5f5"}; return "black";})
        })
    }
});
'''

How to read the graph?¶

As you go through the tabs you will notice that most display higher numbers along a diagonal path, this is normal because as the expert's age increases he becomes more experienced with his coding skills. If the diagonal as a whole is lower, or there is a large concentration of people below the diagonal in the graph we learn that a lot more individuals are managing with lower coding experience than what is the norm. Conversely, if the whole diagonal is higher or if there is a lot of people above this diagonal, then the field might require more coding experience than what is the norm in other fields

For the most part, we see the same tendencies with data professionals in the age group 22 - 29 having around 1-5 years of coding experience. Such experience is well within the range of the average student. Once again we see Product Managers(and "Others") deviating quite a bit from the normal trend, with their coding experience falling short of the normal "diagonal" trend we see otherwise.

A couple other interesting points to note when looking at the different views of the graph:

  • Database Engineers seem to be the most experienced of the bunch with 44% of respondents having 10+ years of experience(and 65% with 5+ years). This is followed by Research Scientists and Software Engineers.
  • Product Managers still defy norms with the highest percentage of individuals that haven't written code(11%), while at the same time having the 4th highest percentage of respondents with 20+ years experience.

Some of the key takeaways are:

  • The students seem to be on a strong start here - learning Python is not only a safe bet because of its widespread use in the industry, but its also by far the language most recommended to beginners.
  • Having at least a basic understanding of SQL and database management would go a long way in your career.
  • While languages like C, C++ and Java are what many of us start out with, students should learn to quickly adapt and transfer their knowledge to more commonly used languages.

    d3.csv('viztools.csv', function(data) {
    //d3.csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/schubert-da/Kaggle_DS_Survey_data/main/viz.csv', function(data) {
    

    var fontsizes = {
        "Matplotlib": "80px",
        "Seaborn": "60px",
        "Plotly": "32px",
        "Ggplot": "32px",
        "Shiny": "30px",
        "D3": "28px",
        "Altair": "0px",
        "Bokeh": "28px",
        "Geoplotlib": "28px",
        "Leaflet": "0px",
        "None": "28px",
        "Other": "0px"
    }
      // stratify the data: reformatting for d3.js
      var root = d3.stratify()
        .id(function(d) { return d.name; })   // Name of the entity (column name is name in csv)
        .parentId(function(d) { return d.parent; })   // Name of the parent (column name is parent in csv)
        (data);
      root.sum(function(d) { return +d.value })   // Compute the numeric value for each entity
    
      // Then d3.treemap computes the position of each element of the hierarchy
      // The coordinates are added to the root object above
      d3.treemap()
        .size([width, height])
        .padding(4)
        (root)
    
      // use this information to add rectangles:
      svg
        .selectAll("rect")
        .data(root.leaves())
        .enter()
        .append("rect")
            .attr('x', function (d) { return d.x0; })
            .attr('y', function (d) { return d.y0; })
            .attr('width', function (d) { return d.x1 - d.x0; })
            .attr('height', function (d) { return d.y1 - d.y0; })
            .style("stroke", "black")
            .style("fill", function (d) { return colorScale(d.value); })
            .on("mouseover", function(d){
                let tooltip = d3.selectAll(".tooltip")

                tooltip
                    .html(tooltip_text[d.data.name].replace("%s",colorScale(d.data.value)))
                    .style("display","block")
                    .style("height", "0px")
                    .transition()
                    .duration(200)
                    .style("height", "325px")
            })
            .on("mouseleave", function(d){
                d3.selectAll(".tooltip")
                .style("display","none")
                .style("height", "0px")
            })
            
            


      // and to add the text labels
        svg
        .selectAll("text")
        .data(root.leaves())
        .enter()
        .append("text")
            .attr("x", function(d){ return d.x0+10})    // +10 to adjust position (more right)
            .attr("y", function(d){ return d.y0+20})    // +20 to adjust position (lower)
            .text(function(d){ return d.data.name})
            .attr("font-size", "18px")
            .attr("fill", "white")
            .on("mouseover", function(d){
                let tooltip = d3.selectAll(".tooltip")

                tooltip
                    .html(tooltip_text[d.data.name].replace("%s",colorScale(d.data.value)))
                    .style("display","block")
                    .style("height", "325px")
            })
          

        svg
        .selectAll("text.count")
        .data(root.leaves())
        .enter()
        .append("text")
            .attr("class", function(d){ return "count "+d.data.name})
            .attr("x", function(d){ return (d.x1+d.x0)/2 })    // +10 to adjust position (more right)
            .attr("y", function(d){ return (d.y1+d.y0)/2 + 20})    // +20 to adjust position (lower)
            .text(function(d){ return d.data.value.replace(/\B(?=(\d{3})+(?!\d))/g, ",");})
            .attr("text-anchor","middle")
            .style("font-size", function(d){ return fontsizes[d.data.name] })
            .attr("fill", "white")
            .style("-webkit-font-smoothing", "antialiased")
            .style("font-family", "Arial")
            .on("mouseover", function(d){
                let tooltip = d3.selectAll(".tooltip")

                tooltip
                    .html(tooltip_text[d.data.name].replace("%s",colorScale(d.data.value)))
                    .style("display","block")
                    .style("height", "326px")
            })
        })
        
});

Document What should I use to visualize my data?

While the majority of our data professionals have experience with Matplotlib and Seaborn,
a lot of the libraries do see a fair amount of use in vizualisation.

From the above graph my main takeaway is that with visualization greatly aiding analysis its often useful to have experience with at least one of these tools under your belt. If your job role hinges on creating impactful visualisations, then maybe you might need to upskill yourself and learn to utilise tools with interactivity and higher degrees of customisation that help to convey your message better.

3.6 How much Machine Learning Experience do I need?
¶

As students just starting out in their machine learning journey, it isn't uncommon to think that whatever ML knowledge we have isn't quite enough to make that first step into working in an ML-related role. Let's try to get a better understanding of how experienced data professionals are with machine learning at different age groups.

Much like the coding experience graph, you can use the buttons to get more field-specific insights. Note that cells without any text implies a count of zero.

Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q15. For how many years have you used machine learning methods?

# Creating the CSV for d3 to use.

# Creating the new labels for renaming, also defining the order of the labels in the graph
ml_labels = ['< 1 year', '1-2 years', '2-3 years','5-10 years', '3-4 years', 'Do not use','4-5 years','10-20 years', '> 20 years']
ordered_ml_labels = ['Do not use','< 1 year', '1-2 years', '2-3 years','3-4 years','4-5 years','5-10 years','10-20 years','> 20 years']

# We will create the data for the 'all' tab of the visualisation
ml_age_heatmap = pd.DataFrame()

# This line just helps to make sure that all the required indexes(ML experience labels) are present in the df, ignore the values we will just drop the column later anyways
ml_age_heatmap["placeholder"] =  dataprofs["Q15"].value_counts()

for agegroup in student_ages.keys():
    ml_age_heatmap[agegroup] = dataprofs[dataprofs["Q1"]==agegroup]["Q15"].value_counts()

# Dropping the placeholder col, rename the labels and then reorder them    
ml_age_heatmap = ml_age_heatmap.drop("placeholder",axis=1)
ml_age_heatmap.index = ml_labels
ml_age_heatmap = ml_age_heatmap.reindex(ordered_ml_labels)
  
    
mlexpdata = ml_age_heatmap.values
mlexpdata_list = []

for row in range(mlexpdata.shape[0]):
    for col in range(mlexpdata.shape[1]):
        mlexpdata_list.append([ordered_ml_labels[row],student_ages.keys()[col],mlexpdata[row][col],"all"])     

# Same procedure as before, now we just iterate and do it once for each field.
for field in fields:
    ml_age_heatmap = pd.DataFrame()
    ml_age_heatmap["placeholder"] =  dataprofs["Q15"].value_counts()
    for agegroup in student_ages.keys():
        ml_age_heatmap[agegroup] = dataprofs[(dataprofs["Q1"]==agegroup) & (dataprofs["Q5"]==field)]["Q15"].value_counts()
    
    ml_age_heatmap = ml_age_heatmap.drop("placeholder",axis=1)
    ml_age_heatmap.index = ml_labels
    ml_age_heatmap = ml_age_heatmap.reindex(ordered_ml_labels)

    mlexpdata = ml_age_heatmap.values

    for row in range(mlexpdata.shape[0]):
        for col in range(mlexpdata.shape[1]):
            mlexpdata_list.append([ordered_ml_labels[row],student_ages.keys()[col],mlexpdata[row][col],field])

# Add column names and write to working directory
mlexpdata_df = pd.DataFrame(mlexpdata_list,columns=['exp', 'age', 'value', 'field'])
mlexpdata_df.to_csv("ml_age_heatmap.csv", index=False)

js_t1 = '''
         require.config({
            paths: {
                d3: "https://d3js.org/d3.v4.min"
             }
             });
        require(["d3"], function(d3) {
        var data;
        // set the dimensions and margins of the graph
        var margin = { top: 5, right: 65, bottom: 60, left: 70 },
            width = 750 - margin.left - margin.right,
            height = 600 - margin.top - margin.bottom;

        // append the svg object to the body of the page
        var svg = d3.select("#my_dataviz3")
            .append("svg")
            .attr("width", width + margin.left + margin.right)
            .attr("height", height + margin.top + margin.bottom)
            .append("g")
            .attr("transform",
                "translate(" + margin.left + "," + margin.top + ")");

        // Labels of row and columns
        var xlabels = ['Do not use', '< 1 year', '1-2 years', '2-3 years', '3-4 years', '4-5 years','5-10 years', '10-20 years', '> 20 years']
        var ylabels = ['18-21', '22-24', '25-29', '30-34', '35-39', '40-44', '45-49', '50-54', '55-59', '60-69', '70+']

        // Build X scales and axis:
        var x = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([0, width])
            .domain(ylabels)
            .padding(0.03);

        svg.append("g")
            .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height + ")")
            .call(d3.axisBottom(x))

        // Build X scales and axis:
        var y = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([height, 0])
            .domain(xlabels)
            .padding(0.03);

        svg.append("g")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y));

        // Build color scale
        var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
            .range(["#f5f5f5", "#29658c"])
            .domain([1, 216])

        showData();
        let buttons = d3.selectAll(".dv3 button")

        buttons
            .on("click", function(){
                showData(this.value)
            })

        function showData(field="all"){
                    d3.csv("ml_age_heatmap.csv", function (data) {
                    
                    data = data.filter(function(d){
                        return d.field == field;
                    })
                    
                    var maxColor = d3.max(data, (d)=>{return +d.value})
                    var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
                    .range(["#f5f5f5", "#29658c"])
                    .domain([1, maxColor])

                    var u = svg.selectAll("rect")
                    .data(data)

                    u
                    .enter()
                    .append("rect")
                    .merge(u)
                    .transition()
                    .duration(1000)
                    .attr("x", function (d) {return x(d.age) })
                    .attr("y", function (d) {return y(d.exp) })
                    .attr("width", x.bandwidth())
                    .attr("height", y.bandwidth())
                    .style("fill", function (d) { if(d.value !=="nan"){return myColor(d.value);} return myColor(1);  })
                    
                    var v = svg.selectAll("svg > g > text")
                    .data(data)

                    v
                    .enter()
                    .append("text")
                    .merge(v)
                    .transition()
                    .duration(1000)
                    .text( function (d) { if(d.value !=="nan" && +d.value != 0){ return +d.value} return " "; })
                    .attr("x", function (d) { return x(d.age) })
                    .attr("y", function (d) { return y(d.exp) })
                    .attr("transform","translate(15,35)")
                    .style("font-family","Didot")
                    .style("font-size","18px")
                    .style("fill", function (d){if(d.value > maxColor/2) { return "#d7d7d7"}; return "black";})
        })
    }
});
'''

# ~3hr for this one, fastest d3 piece so far. Creating the csv for it took a while
Document


While "1 year of ML experience" can mean very different things depending on where the individual studied, hands-on/work experience, how much time they actually devoted to learning, etc, we will use this to get a sense of how experienced individuals are with machine learning techniques, in their fields.

Working with data does not always entail that machine learning be the end goal. This is apparent because in many fields we no longer see the same dominant diagonal concentration of professionals that we saw in the coding experience graph. Professions like data analysts and business analysts both have significant number of individuals that have no ML experience.

In the age group 22-29 most individuals have between 0-2 years of machine learning experience, a very reasonable goal for students to strive towards.

The professions where higher ML experience is observed are those of data scientists, research scientists and machine learning engineers.

3.7 What Machine Learning frameworks should I opt for?
¶

Let's try to see what ML frameworks are commonly used in the industry.

Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q16. Which of the following machine learning frameworks do you use on a regular basis?
In [21]:
q16 = [question for question in questions if 'Q16' in question]

# List of labels
mlframeworks = []
for qn in q16:
    for val in dataprofs[qn].unique():
        mlframeworks.append(val)
        
mlframeworks = [str.strip(mlframework) for mlframework in mlframeworks if str(mlframework)!='nan']

mlframeworks_counts = dataprofs[q16].notnull().sum()
mlframeworks_counts.index = mlframeworks
mlframeworks_percentages = (mlframeworks_counts/dataprofs.shape[0]).sort_values(ascending = False)

# Creating graph
trace1 = go.Bar(
    y = mlframeworks_percentages,
    x = mlframeworks_percentages.index,
    marker = dict(color = [primary_blue]+[primary_grey]*15),
)

layout = dict(
    title = "<b style='font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:22px'>Usage of Machine Learning Frameworks</b><br><span style='font-family:Tahoma; font-size:14px'>Scikit-Learn seems to be the go-to choice for most data professionals.</span>",
    margin = dict(t=30, pad=5),
    xaxis = dict(
        categoryorder = 'array',
        categoryarray = mlframeworks_percentages.sort_values(ascending=False).keys(),
        tickangle = -90,
    ),
    yaxis = dict(
        zeroline = True,
        zerolinecolor = "#4d4d4d",
        zerolinewidth = 4,
        gridcolor = "#d7d7d7",
        tickformat = '%'
    ),
    bargap = 0.03,
    width = 600,
    height = 400,
    plot_bgcolor = "#fff"
)

data = [trace1]

fig = go.Figure(data = data, layout = layout)

iplot(fig)

A couple things to note:

  • Scikit is the most common choice among respondents. Tensorflow and Keras also seem to be popular choices in the second and third place.
  • Xgboost vs LightGBM vs CatBoost: A common question asked on Kaggle - when considering only Data Scientists, we see that 49% use Xgboost making it the preferred choice over LightGBM at 26% and Catboost at 14%.

While exploring the data for this analysis I noticed a rather peculiar behaviour - for some reason Statisticians adopted Caret to a much greater extent than any other field. On further analysis I realised that because this was a group that had much higher usages of R, an R ML framework like Caret had a much higher adoption rate. Let's see how the same chart differs if we instead look at those who only use R.

Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q16. Which of the following machine learning frameworks do you use on a regular basis?
In [22]:
r_users = dataprofs[(dataprofs["Q7_Part_1"].isnull()) & (dataprofs["Q7_Part_2"].notnull())]

mlframeworks_r_counts = r_users[q16].count()

trace1 = go.Bar(

Seems like our results have changed when only considering R users. If students prefer R as their language of choice, Caret seems to be a good option to look into (Also notice how another R package like TinyModels suddenly jumped up in the list)

The lower percentages in general compared to the previous graph, as well as the presence of "None" in second place shows that most R users value the language for purposes other than machine learning.

I'm assuming we're seeing certain python packages popping up in this graph because the respondents had knowledge of them but didn't consider Python as a language they used regularly, in the survey responses.

3.8 Learning Platforms
¶

Even with all the amazing resources available online, at times we all need a little guidance in developing a systematic learning plan and thats where learning platforms come to our rescue. Let's take a look at what we can learn from the way that data professionals consume online course content.

While exploring the data I noticed how at each age group there were noticable differences between both groups' learning habits so I created an interactive piece to help you see just that. (PRO TIP: After you've selected an age group option, using the up and down arrow keys to go through the options makes the graph a lot more interesting to use.)

Source: Kaggle 2020 DS and ML Survey - Q37. On which platforms have you begun or completed data science courses?
In [23]:
# Get the questions list
q37 = [question for question in questions if 'Q37' in question]

platforms = []
for qn in q37:
    for val in dataprofs[qn].unique():
        platforms.append(val)
        
platforms = [str.strip(platform) for platform in platforms if str(platform)!='nan']

# Now we start creating the DataFrame for d3 to use

# Professionals counts
platforms_counts = dataprofs[q37].notnull().sum()
platforms_counts.index = platforms

platform_percentages = (platforms_counts/dataprofs.shape[0]).sort_values(ascending = False)
platform_percentages.index = [platform.split("(")[0] for platform in platform_percentages.index]

# Students counts
platforms_students_counts = students[q37].notnull().sum()
platforms_students_counts.index = platforms

platform_students_percentages = (platforms_students_counts/students.shape[0]).sort_values(ascending = False)
platform_students_percentages.index = [platform.split("(")[0] for platform in platform_students_percentages.index]

# Professionals Data - "all" age group
platform_data = pd.DataFrame()
platform_data["platform"] = [platform.split("(")[0].split(" ")[0] for platform in platform_percentages.index]
platform_data["value"] = np.round(platform_percentages.values*100,1)
platform_data["age"] = "all"
platform_data["category"] = "professional"

# Professionals Data - iterate and do the same for remaining age groups
for agegroup in student_ages.keys():
    temp_df = pd.DataFrame()
    
    temp_data = dataprofs[dataprofs["Q1"]==agegroup][q37]
    temp_counts = temp_data.notnull().sum()
    temp_counts.index = platforms

    temp_percentages = (temp_counts/temp_data.shape[0]).sort_values(ascending = False)
    temp_percentages.index = [platform.split("(")[0].split(" ")[0] for platform in temp_percentages.index]
    
    temp_df["platform"] = temp_percentages.index
    temp_df["value"] = np.round(temp_percentages.values*100,1)
    temp_df["age"] = agegroup
    temp_df["category"] = "professional"
    
    platform_data = platform_data.append(temp_df,ignore_index = True)
    
# Students Data - "all" age group
temp_df = pd.DataFrame()
temp_df["platform"] = [platform.split("(")[0].split(" ")[0] for platform in platform_students_percentages.index ]
temp_df["value"] = np.round(platform_students_percentages.values*100,1)
temp_df["age"] = "all"
temp_df["category"] = "student"
platform_data = platform_data.append(temp_df,ignore_index = True)

# Students Data - iterate and do the same for remaining age groups
for agegroup in student_ages.keys():
    temp_df = pd.DataFrame()
    
    temp_data = students[students["Q1"]==agegroup][q37]
    temp_counts = temp_data.notnull().sum()
    temp_counts.index = platforms

    temp_percentages = (temp_counts/temp_data.shape[0]).sort_values(ascending = False)
    temp_percentages.index = [platform.split("(")[0].split(" ")[0] for platform in temp_percentages.index]
    
    temp_df["platform"] = temp_percentages.index
    temp_df["value"] = np.round(temp_percentages.values*100,1)
    temp_df["age"] = agegroup
    temp_df["category"] = "student"
    
    platform_data = platform_data.append(temp_df,ignore_index = True)

platform_data.to_csv("platform_full.csv", index=False, header=["platform","value","age","category"])

js_t1 = '''
         require.config({
            paths: {
                d3: "https://d3js.org/d3.v4.min"
             }
             });
        require(["d3"], function(d3) {
        
        // set the dimensions and margins of the graph
        var margin = {top: 20, right: 0, bottom: 40, left: 90},
            width = 360 - margin.left - margin.right,
            height = 400 - margin.top - margin.bottom;
        
        // append the svg object to the body of the page
        var svg = d3.select("#my_dataviz41")
          .append("svg")
            .attr("width", width + margin.left + margin.right)
            .attr("height", height + margin.top + margin.bottom)
          .append("g")
            .attr("transform", "translate(" + margin.left + "," + margin.top + ")");

        var svg2 = d3.select("#my_dataviz42")
            .append("svg")
                .attr("width", width + margin.left + margin.right)
                .attr("height", height + margin.top + margin.bottom)
            .append("g")
                .attr("transform", "translate(" + margin.left + "," + margin.top + ")");
        
        var x = d3.scaleLinear()
            .domain([0, 56])
            .range([ 0, width]);

        showData();

        var sel = d3.selectAll("div.dv4 .age_select")
                    .on("change", function(){
                        showData(this.value)
                    })
                    .transition()

        var x = d3.scaleLinear()
            .domain([0, 56])
            .range([ 0, width]);
        
        var xAxis = svg.append("g")
            .attr("transform", "translate(0,0)")
            .call(d3.axisTop(x))

        var xAxis2 = svg2.append("g")
            .attr("transform", "translate(0,0)")
            .call(d3.axisTop(x))
        
        var y = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([ 0, height ])
            .domain(['Coursera',
                    'Udemy',
                    'Kaggle Learn Courses',
                    'University Courses ',
                    'DataCamp',
                    'edX',
                    'Udacity',
                    'LinkedIn Learning',
                    'Other',
                    'Fast.ai',
                    'Cloud-certification programs ',
                    'None'])
            .padding(.1);
        
        var yAxis =svg.append("g")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y))

            var yAxis2 =svg2.append("g")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y))
        
        function showData(age="all") {
        d3.csv("platform_full.csv", function(data){
        
        var data_prof = data.filter(function(d){
                        return ((d.category == "professional") && (d.age == age));
                    })
        data_prof = data_prof.sort(function(b,a){ return +a.value - (+b.value); })

        var data_stud = data.filter(function(d){
            return ((d.category == "student") && (d.age == age));
        })
        data_stud = data_stud.sort(function(b,a){ return +a.value - (+b.value); })

        x.domain([0, 56])
        xAxis.transition().duration(500).call(d3.axisTop(x))

        y.domain(data_prof.map(function(d) { return d.platform; }))
        yAxis.transition().duration(500).call(d3.axisLeft(y))
        
        var max_stud = d3.max(data_stud, d => +d.value)
        var max_prof = d3.max(data_prof, d => +d.value)
        
        //  Bars
        var d1 = svg.selectAll(".rect1")
            .data(data_prof)

        d1
        .enter()
        .append("rect")
        .merge(d1)
        .attr("class", "rect1")
        .attr("x", x(0) )
        .attr("y", function(d) { return y(d.platform); })
        .transition()
        .duration(1000)
        .attr("width", function(d) { return x(d.value); })
        .attr("height", y.bandwidth() )
        .attr("fill", (d) => { return (+d.value == max_prof? "#496595": "#c6ccd8") })

        var v = svg.selectAll("#my_dataviz41 > svg > g > text")
                    .data(data_prof)

        v
        .enter()
        .append("text")
        .merge(v)
        .transition()
        .duration(1000)
        .text( function (d) { if(d.value !=="nan" && +d.value != 0){ return (d.value).split(".")[0] + "%"} return " "; })
        .attr("x", function (d) { return x(d.value) })
        .attr("y", function (d) { return y(d.platform) })
        .attr("transform","translate(-27,17)")
        .style("font-family","Didot")
        .style("font-size","13px")
        .style("fill","#fff")
        
        x.domain([0, 56])
        xAxis2.transition().duration(500).call(d3.axisTop(x))
        
        y.domain(data_stud.map(function(d) { return d.platform; }))
        yAxis2.transition().duration(500).call(d3.axisLeft(y))
        
        //  Bars
        var d2 = svg2.selectAll("rect")
                    .data(data_stud)

        d2
        .enter()
        .append("rect")
        .merge(d2)
        .attr("class", "rect2")
        .attr("x", x(0) )
        .attr("y", function(d) { return y(d.platform); })
        .transition()
        .duration(1000)
        .attr("width", function(d) { return x(d.value); })
        .attr("height", y.bandwidth() )
        .attr("fill", (d) => { return (+d.value == max_stud? "#496595": "#c6ccd8") })

        var w = svg2.selectAll("#my_dataviz42 > svg > g > text")
                    .data(data_stud)

        w
        .enter()
        .append("text")
        .merge(w)
        .transition()
        .duration(1000)
        .text( function (d) { if(d.value !=="nan" && +d.value != 0){ return (d.value).split(".")[0] + "%"} return " "; })
        .attr("x", function (d) { return x(d.value) })
        .attr("y", function (d) { return y(d.platform) })
        .attr("transform","translate(-27,17)")
        .style("font-family","Didot")
        .style("font-size","13px")
        .style("fill","#fff")
        })
    }
});
'''
