         require.config({
            paths: {
                d3: "https://d3js.org/d3.v4.min"
             }
             });
        require(["d3"], function(d3) {
        
         var margin_heatmap_ml = {top: 40, right: 20, bottom: 40, left: 60},
        width_heatmap_ml = 350 - margin_heatmap_ml.left - margin_heatmap_ml.right,
        height_heatmap_ml = 340 - margin_heatmap_ml.top - margin_heatmap_ml.bottom;
        
        // append the svg object to the body of the page
        var svg_heatmap_ml = d3.select("#ml_heatmap")
        .append("svg")
        .attr("width", width_heatmap_ml + margin_heatmap_ml.left + margin_heatmap_ml.right)
        .attr("height", height_heatmap_ml + margin_heatmap_ml.top + margin_heatmap_ml.bottom)
        .append("g")
        .attr("transform",
                "translate(" + margin_heatmap_ml.left + "," + margin_heatmap_ml.top + ")");
        
        // add title
        svg_heatmap_ml.append("text")
            .text("Company and DS team sizes")
            .attr("x",0)
            .attr("y",-10)
            .style("font-family", "Times New Roman")
            .style("font-size", "21px") 

        svg_heatmap_ml.append("text")
            .text("Company size (employees)")
            .attr("x", width_heatmap_ml/2)
            .attr("y", height_heatmap_ml + 32)
            .attr("text-anchor","middle")
            .style("font-weight","600")
            .style("font-family", "Tahoma")
            .style("font-size", "12px")
        
        svg_heatmap_ml.append("text")
            .attr("transform", "rotate(-90)")
            .attr("y", 0 - margin_heatmap_ml.left + 6)
            .attr("x",0 - (height_heatmap_ml / 2))
            .attr("dy", "1em")
            .style("text-anchor", "middle")
            .style("font-weight","600")
            .style("font-family", "Tahoma")
            .style("font-size", "13px") 
            .text("Data Science team size");  
                        
        // Labels of row and columns
        var myGroups = ['0-49', '50-249', '250-999', '1000-9,999', '10,000 or more']
        var myVars = ['0', '1-2', '3-4', '5-9', '10-14', '15-19', '20+']
        
        // Build X scales and axis:
        var x = d3.scaleBand()
        .range([ 0, width_heatmap_ml ])
        .domain(myGroups)
        .padding(0.01);
        svg_heatmap_ml.append("g")
        .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height_heatmap_ml + ")")
        .call(d3.axisBottom(x))
        .selectAll("text")
            .style("font-size","9px")
        
        // Build X scales and axis:
        var y = d3.scaleBand()
        .range([ height_heatmap_ml, 0 ])
        .domain(myVars)
        .padding(0.01);
        svg_heatmap_ml.append("g")
        .call(d3.axisLeft(y));
        
        // Build color scale
        var myColor = d3.scaleLinear()
        .range(["#f7f7f7", "#29658c"]) //e9cf87
        .domain([1,1200])
        
        //Read the data
        d3.csv("ml_heatmap.csv", function(data) {
        
        svg_heatmap_ml.selectAll()
            .data(data)
            .enter()
            .append("rect")
            .attr("x", function(d) { return x(d.cosize) })
            .attr("y", function(d) { return y(d.dssize) })
            .attr("width", x.bandwidth() )
            .attr("height", y.bandwidth() )
            .style("fill", function(d) { return myColor(d.value)} )
        
        })

        var margin_mlexp_ml = {top: 35, right: 20, bottom: 40, left: 70},
            width_mlexp_ml  = 350 - margin_mlexp_ml.left - margin_mlexp_ml.right,
            height_mlexp_ml = 340 - margin_mlexp_ml.top - margin_mlexp_ml.bottom;

        var svg_mlexp_ml = d3.select("#ml_mlexp_ml")
            .append("svg")
                .attr("width", width_mlexp_ml + margin_mlexp_ml.left + margin_mlexp_ml.right)
                .attr("height", height_mlexp_ml + margin_mlexp_ml.top + margin_mlexp_ml.bottom)
            .append("g")
                .attr("transform",
                    "translate(" + margin_mlexp_ml.left + "," + margin_mlexp_ml.top + ")");
        
        svg_mlexp_ml.append("text")
            .text("Machine Learning experience")
            .attr("x",-5)
            .attr("y",-10)
            .style("font-family", "Times New Roman")
            .style("font-size", "21px")
            
        svg_mlexp_ml.append("text")
            .text("Respondent's count")
            .attr("x", width_mlexp_ml/2 - 10)
            .attr("y", height_mlexp_ml + 32)
            .attr("text-anchor","middle")
            .style("font-weight","600")
            .style("font-family", "Tahoma")
            .style("font-size", "12px")

        d3.csv("ml_mlexp.csv", function(data) {

            // data = data.sort((a,b) => d3.descending(+a.value, +b.value))
            var max = d3.max(data, d=> +d.value)

            // Add X axis
            var x = d3.scaleLinear()
                .domain([0, 2000])
                .range([ 0, width_mlexp_ml]);
            svg_mlexp_ml.append("g")
                .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height_mlexp_ml + ")")
                .call(d3.axisBottom(x))
                .selectAll("text")
                    .attr("transform", "translate(-10,0)")
                    .style("text-anchor", "end");

            // Y axis
            var y = d3.scaleBand()
            .range([ 0, height_mlexp_ml ])
            .domain(data.map(function(d) { return d.exp; }))
            .padding(.05);
            svg_mlexp_ml.append("g")
            .call(d3.axisLeft(y))
                .selectAll("text")
                .style("font-family", "Tahoma")
                .style("font-size", "11px")

            // Bars
            svg_mlexp_ml.selectAll("myRect")
            .data(data)
            .enter()
            .append("rect")
                .attr("x", x(0) )
                .attr("y", function(d) { return y(d.exp); })
                .attr("width", function(d) { return x(d.value); })
                .attr("height", y.bandwidth() )
                .attr("fill", (d) => { return (+d.value == max? "#3f4d63": "#c6ccd8") })
            })

});
'''

h = display(HTML(htmlt1))

Note
¶

As we have reached the end of the notebook, one might notice that I haven't touched on the topics of business intelligence tools, database specifics, big data products, ML automation, etc. The reason for this is not that I don't find these products relevant in the workplace, but rather that I felt that the choice of these tools are often dependent on existing company practices, rather than personal preference.

While it could help to be familiar with these tools, I preferred to focus attention on the other tools/languages that form the core part of their foundations in working with data.

5. Conclusion
¶

I understand that throughout the course of this notebook I have bombarded you with a lot of information on working with data. It is easy to feel a little overwhelmed by all the different moving parts involved and think that you might have bit off a bit more than you can chew when you decided to try your hand at data science, especially when you are just starting out.

To this, I'd like to remind you that noone enters their first job( or even switching to a new role) knowing everything on day one - you will learn as you work and you are allowed to( and will) make mistakes. It's just a desire to learn and improve which makes things easier.

Thanks for joining me in this journey and I hope you found something of use in this notebook. Stay safe and keep learning!

Massive thanks to these resources / notebooks on kaggle
¶

  • Plotly Tutorial for Beginners: I was hesitant to switch away from my beloved Seaborn until I saw this notebook. The code in this notebook is clean and easy to understand. It showcases a wide range of plotly graphs and presents their code in a very "to-the-point" manner.
  • Interactive D3.js Visualisations in Kaggle Kernels: Prior to this notebook I didn't know what D3 was, let alone that Kaggle supported it. I would definitely recommend it as a resource for getting your D3 visualisations up and running in Kaggle Notebooks.
  • The D3 Graph Gallery: D3 is a pain if you're going to create every graph from scratch. I tend to start every graph by taking the bare bones code from here, plugging in my own data and then modifying/adding interactivity as needed.

  • Treasure Hunt - what gives to be REALLY good?: Andrada's book was the first time I saw someone handle pays to remove regional biasing, albeit she goes the more fun route with the McMeal index.
